content:
Yes, a higher concentration of electric charge compared to ground creates a higher voltage.

In an electrical circuit, the electric potential difference, or voltage, between two points is proportional to the amount of electric charge stored at those points. If one point has a higher concentration of electric charge compared to ground or another point, it will have a higher voltage. This difference in voltage drives the flow of electric current through the circuit, as charged particles are attracted to points with lower voltage and repelled by points with higher voltage.

In practice, the voltage at a point is often measured relative to a reference point, such as ground. In this case, the voltage difference between two points is equal to the difference in electric potential energy per unit charge between those points.
